conclusion: Determine if the pedestrian can catch up with the bus by analyzing velocity-time graphs.
The image shows two velocity-time graphs: one for the pedestrian with a constant slope, and one for the bus with a positive slope.
The pedestrian is running at a constant speed.
The bus starts moving with uniform acceleration after the light turns green.
The pedestrian is initially 36 meters away from the bus.
The bus's velocity increases linearly with time.
The bus will cover the 36 meters if its velocity at time t results in a distance traveled of 36 meters.
The pedestrian's time to cover 36 meters is distance divided by speed.
Compare the time taken by the bus to cover 36 meters with the pedestrian's time to determine if the pedestrian can catch up.
The graph shows that the bus reaches the same velocity as the pedestrian after some time.
Since the bus reaches the same velocity as the pedestrian, it will eventually catch up with the pedestrian.
